Proportional Plus Derivative Controllers (PD)
â€¢ The stability and overshoot problems that arise when a proportional controller is used at high
gain can be mitigated by

adding a term proportional to the time-derivative of the error signal.
The value of the damping can be adjusted to achieve a critically damped response.

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_376_0]



Proportional Plus Derivative Co

ntrollers (PD)
â€¢ The higher the error signal rate of change, the sooner the final control element
is positioned to the desired value.
â€¢ The added derivative action reduces initial overshoot of the measured variable,
and therefore aids in stabilizing the pr

ocess sooner.
â€¢ This control mode is called proportional plus derivative (PD) control because the
derivative section responds to the rate of change of the error signal.

Tips for Designing a PID Controllers
1. Obtain an open-loop response and determine what needs

to be improved.
2. Add a proportional control to improve the rise time .
3. Add a derivative control to improve the overshoot.
4. Add an integral control to eliminate the steady-state error.
5. Adjust each of K , K , and K until you obtain a desired overa

ll response.
p i d
â€¢ Lastly, please keep in mind that you do not need to implement all three controllers
(proportional, derivative, and integral) into a single system, if not necessary. For example, if
a PI controller gives a good enough response, then you

don't need to implement derivative
controller to the system. Keep the controller as simple as possible.

K-Fold Cross Validation
â–ª K-Fold is a well-known form of cross-validation.
â–ª Steps:
1. Partition the dataset into k equal-sized partitions.
2. Select one partition as the validation data.
3. Use the remaining k-1 as the training data.
4. Train the model and determine accuracy from the validation data.
5. Repeat the process k times, selecting a different partition each time for the
validation data.
6. Average t

he accuracy results.

Confusion Matrix
Is accuracy is the best measure?
Accuracy may not be a good measure if the
dataset is not balanced (both negative and
positive classes have different numbers of data
instances). We will explain this with an example.
Consider the following scenario: There are 90 people who
are healthy (negative) and 10 people who have some
disease (positive). Now letâ€™s say our machine learning
model perfectly classified the 90 people as healthy but it
als

o classified the unhealthy people as healthy. What will
Confusion matrix for healthy vs unhealthy
happen in this scenario? Let us see the confusion matrix
people classification task.
and find out the accuracy.
The accuracy, in this case, is 90 % but this model is very poor because
all the 10 people who are unhealthy are classified as healthy.

WHAT IS AN EXPERT SYSTEM ?
â–ª An Expert System (ES) is an exampl

e of a knowledge-based system. It was introduced around 1965 at
Stanford by Edward Feigenbaum.
â–ª â€œES is a computer program that uses artificial intelligence (AI) technologies to simulate the judgment
and behavior of a human or an organization that has expert knowledge and experience in a
particular field such as medical diagnosis, account, coding, and games, etc.â€
â–ª ES gathers data by asking the user questions about the problem. An initial set of questions can lead
to further questions depending on the user

â€™s responses.
â–ª The ES reasons what questions it needs to ask, based on the knowledge it is given. It will use the
responses from users to rule out various possibilities that will allow it eventually reach a decision or
diagnosis.

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_124_0]



WHAT IS AN EXPERT SYSTEM ?
â€¢ We rely on expert systems to help us with knowledge and understanding in a particular field.
We use them the same way as certain experts in our lives.
â€¢ For example, we will see a d

octor if we have a health problem, or we will see a car mechanic
if our car will not start.
â€¢ We can similarly use an expert system; it will ask us questions about our health problem or
car problem and provide us with a diagnosis or course of action.
â€¢ ES is designed to try and replicate the judgment of a human that has expert knowledge in a
certain field. By doing this they can be used to replace or assist a human expert.

Why Develop Expert System
â–ª Human expertise:
â€¢ In short supply (few experts on task)

â€¢ Expensive to develop or hire
â€¢ Hard to get a hold of in a hurry
âœ“ Expertise difficult to apply quickly (complex tasks)
âœ“ Impractical to have humans constantly on call
â€¢ Can be lost
âœ“ Retirement/Leave job
âœ“ Death
â–ª ES serves the following functions with respect to expertise:
â€¢ Document/preserve
â€¢ Reproduce/make available
â€¢ Teach/disseminate
â–ª Computers do not get bored/tired/frustrated/scared

stems

â–ª First attempt unlikely to be very successful

edge base refinement.

The General Design of an Expert System

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_130_0]



Knowledge Base
â–ª The developers of the expert system will interview a collection of experts to build the
database of knowledge.
â–ª They will look to gain two types of knowledge from the experts.
â–ª The first is factual

knowledge. This is the knowledge that is widely shared.
â–ª The second type is heuristic knowledge. This is the knowledge that is more personal and is
acquired through a range of experiences and reasoning.

Knowledge Base
â–ª Once the knowledge base is built, it can be used by the expert system to inform the question
sit needs to ask and assist in providing the results.
â–ª Part of the knowledge base is the rule base. The rule base is a set of rules that will be used
to produce an output or decision by the expert

system. These rules are used by the
inference engine as a base for reasoning, to obtain a solution to a problem or a decision.
â–ª Each rule will contain two parts, the IF and the THEN. A rule can also have multiple IF parts
that will be joined together by Boolean operators including AND and OR.
â–ª Most ES will have a knowledge-based editor built into them. This allows the knowledge base
to be checked for errors and edited and updated when needed.

Inference Engine
â–ª It will ask the user questions and based o

n their answer it will follow a line of logic. This may
then lead to further questions and eventually a final result.
â–ª The inference engine is mostly a problem-solving tool. It organizes and controls steps to
solve the problem. To do this it often uses a chaining method. It chains together what is
known as IF-THEN rules to form a line of reasoning.
â–ª The IF part of the rule is a condition, for example, IF I am hungry. The Then part of the rule
is an action, for IF I am hungry THEN I will need to eat.

Infe

rence Engine
â–ª There are two main methods that can be used to obtain a result. The appropriate one will
depend on whether the expert system is designed to produce a final result i.e., a diagnosis
or course of action, or if it begins with a known conclusion i.e., goal.
â–ª If the process starts with a set of conditions and chaining moves towards a final conclusion,
this is called forward chaining.
â–ª If the process starts with a known conclusion, but the path to it is unknown, the chaining is
called backward ch

aining.

Inference Engine-Forward Chaining
â–ª In a forward chaining system, the ES will take the data input and match it to the
knowledge and rules it contains. It will keep doing this until I can reach an end goal or
outcome. Therefore, we can say a forward chaining system is data-driven.
â–ª Data is gathered about the problem and then the system infers what it can from the
data to reach a conclusion.

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_135_0]



Inference Engine-Backward Chaining
â–ª W

ith this strategy, an expert system finds out the answer to the question, â€œWhy
â–ª On the basis of what has already happened, the Inference Engine tries to find out which
conditions could have happened in the past for this result.

User Interface
â–ª The user interface is the way the
user interacts with the expert
system.
â–ª They are often graphical in nature
and have a range of selection
processes or typing methods to
allow the user to provide responses.

Shallow Expert System vs Deep Ex

pert System
â–ª Shallow Expert Systems are first-generation architecture expert systems, and which lack causal
knowledge (knowledge of the underlying causes and effects in a system) while Deep Expert
Systems are second-generation architecture expert systems that alleviate first-generation
architecture expert systemsâ€™ limitations.
â–ª Shallow Expert Systems use surface knowledge which can only represent expertise while Deep
Expert Systems use deep knowledge which can represent complex structured objects using
ob

ject models.
â–ª Shallow Expert Systems use rule-based reasoning while Deep Expert Systems combine both
rule-based reasoning and model-based reasoning.
â–ª Shallow Expert Systems use heuristics or heuristic rules or rules of thumb, which do not
guarantee optimal solutions while Deep Expert Systems use the A* algorithm which guarantees
optimality by finding solutions in reasonable computation time, in terms of, number of
transformations and steps of a search.

MYCIN: Early Medical Diagnostic System (1970s)

MYCIN: Early Medical Diagnostic System (1970s)
â–ª MYCIN was the earliest designed expert system at Stanford University in the 1970s.
â–ª Its job was to diagnose and recommend treatm

ent for certain blood infections.
â–ª MYCIN was written in LISP Programming Language.
â–ª ~ 600 rules to diagnose the presence of certain bacteria and recommend antibiotics.
â–ª Combined rules in a more sophisticated way (Bayesian inference)
â–ª Never used in practice due to ethical concerns.
â–ª Inspired the creation of development environments for others who DID make expert
systems that were put into use.

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_143_0]



MYCIN: Early Medical Diagnostic System (

1970s)
â–ª MYCIN represented its knowledge as a set of IF-THEN rules with certainty factors. The
following is an English version of one of MYCIN's rules:
IF the infection is primary-bacteremia
AND the site of the culture is one of the sterile sites
AND the suspected portal of entry is the gastrointestinal tract
THEN there is suggestive evidence (0.7) that infection is bacteroid.
â–ª The 0.7 is roughly the certainty that the conclusion will be true given the evidence. If
the evidence is uncertain, the certaintie

s of the bits of evidence will be combined
with the certainty of the rule to give the certainty of the conclusion.

ment is a generalized expression of knowledge, also just called a fact.

PyKE: Pattern Matching
â€¢ Literal Patterns:
â€¢ Look exactly like data
family.son_of(son, father, mother)
â€¢ Only match themselves.
â€¢ Serve as inputs to Pyke.
â€¢ Used when asking â€œ Is statement X true?â€
â€¢ Pattern Variables:
â€¢ Serve as output parameters.
family.son_of($son, father, mother)
â€¢ Start with a $.
â€¢ Either bound to a value (literal pattern) or unbound.
â€¢ Used when asking â€œ Who are the sons of

Thomas and Norma?â€
â€¢ Anonymous pattern variables:
family.son_of($son, $_father, mother)
â€¢ Start with $ and an underscore ($_).
â€¢ Never bound to values.
â€¢ Used when asking â€œWho are Normaâ€™s sons?â€ and donâ€™t care who are father is.

PyKE: Rules
â–ª Rules have two parts:
â–ª If part (containing a list of statements called the premises)
â–ª The part (containing a list of statements called the conclusions)
â–ª Each of these if and the parts contain on

e or more facts or goals
Syntax: If [A], [B], and [C], Then [D] and [E]
Semantics: If A, B and C are true, then D and E are true.
â€¢ In order to make the rule succeed, Pyke tries to match all statements with facts within the if
clause through a process called backtracking.

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_170_0]



PyKE: Backtracking
While processing the list premises (A, B, C in the graph)
Within a ruleâ€™s if clause:
â–ª If succeeds at proving a premise:
â€¢ Proceed down to the next p

remise in the list.
â€¢ Trying to proceed down from the last premise in the
list (when it succeeds) causes the rule to succeed.
â–ª If fails at proving a premise:
â€¢ Back up to the prior premise in the list and try to
find another solution for it.
â€¢ Trying to back up from the first premise in the list
(when it fails) causes the rule to fail.

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_171_0]



PyKE: Forward Chaining Rules
â€¢ Use â€œ Foreachâ€, â€œAssertâ€ rather than â€œIfâ€, â€œThenâ€
â€¢ Steps:
1. Pyke star

ts with the if clause of the first rule and checks to see if it matches the known
facts
2. If so, it proceeds to the then clause of that rule (firing the rule) to asset a new fact.
3. These new facts may fire other forward-chaining rules by matching their if clause.
4. The process keeps going until no more rules could be fired.

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_172_0]



PyKE: Backward Chaining Rules
â€¢ Use â€œ Useâ€, â€œWhenâ€ rather than â€œThenâ€, â€œIfâ€
â€¢ Steps:
1. Pyke starts by finding

a rule whose then part matches the goal.
2. Pyke then tries to prove all the subgoals in the if part of that rule
â€¢ Some of these subgoals are matched against facts
â€¢ Others are matched with then part of other backward-chaining rules.
3. If all of the subgoals are proved, the rule succeeds, and the original goal is proven.
Otherwise, the rule fails, and Pyke tries to find another rule, and so on.

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_173_0]

How to search for solutions?
â–ª Two Search Types:
â€¢ Uninformed search (blind search)
âœ“ No information about the number of steps or the path cost from the current state to the goal.
âœ“ All they can do is distinguish a goal state from a non-goal state.
â€¢ Informed search (heuristic search)
âœ“ Use some information about a goal state.

Search Strategies Performance Measure
â–ª A search strategy is defined by picking the order of node ex

pansion.
â–ª Strategies are evaluated along the following dimensions:
â€¢ Completeness: does it always find a solution if one exists?
â€¢ Time complexity: number of nodes generated.
â€¢ Space complexity: maximum number of nodes in memory.
â€¢ Optimality: does it always find a least-cost solution?
â€¢ Systematicity: does it visit each state at most once?
â–ª Time and space complexity are measured in terms of
â€¢ b: maximum branching factor of the search tree.
â€¢ d: depth of the least-cost solution.
â€¢ m: maximum depth of the

state space (maybe âˆ)

Uninformed
Search

1. Breadth-first Search (BFS)
â–ª
All the nodes at depth d in the search tree are expanded before the nodes at depth d+1.

1. Breadth-first Search (BFS)
Advantage
â–ª If there is a solution, breadth-first search is guaranteed to find it.
â–ª If there are several solutions, breadth-first search will always find the
shallowest goal state first.
Drawbacks
â–ª All the leaf nodes of the tree must be
maintained

in memory at the same time,

The iterative deepening algorithm is a

combination of DFS and BFS algorithms. This
search algorithm finds out the best depth

it until a goal is found.
This algorithm performs depth-first search

up to a certain "depth limit", and it keeps
increasing the depth limit after each
iteration until the goal node is found.

6. Bidirectional search
Bidirec

tional search algorithm runs two simultaneous
â–ª
searches, one form initial state called as forward-search and
other from goal node called as backward-search, to find the
goal node.
Bidirectional search replaces one single search graph with
â–ª
two small subgraphs in which one starts the search from an
initial vertex and the other starts from the goal vertex.
The search stops when these two graphs intersect each other.

Bidirectional search can use search techniques such as BFS,
â–ª
DFS, DLS, etc.
In bidirectio

nal search, one should know the goal state in

advance.

â–ª Best-first Search

rst Search algorithms with different evaluation

â–ª Two basic approaches

Greedy Search: Minimize Estimated Cost to
Reach a Goal
â–ª For most problems, the cost of reaching the goal from a particular state can be
estimated but cannot be determined exactly.
â–ª A functi

on that calculates such cost estimates is called a heuristic function
(usually denoted by the letter h):
â€¢ h(n) = estimated cost of the cheapest path from the state at node n to a
goal state
â€¢
A best-first search that uses h to select the next node to expand is called greedy search.
â€¢
Strictly speaking, h can be any function at all. We will require only that h(n) = 0 if n is a goal.

ristic that measures cheapest path from current node to goal node?
h (n) = straight line distance (SLD) between n and the goal location
SLD

Greedy Search in the Example (From Arad to Bucharest)
Greedy search prefers to take the biggest bite
possible out of the remaining cost to reach the
goal, without worrying about whether this will be
best in the long run.

â–ª Greedy Search
â€¢
Minimize the estimated cost to the goal h(n)
â–ª Uniform-cost Search
â€¢
Minimize the cost the p

ath so far, g(n)
â–ª Can we combine these two strategies to get the advantages of both?

Minimizing the Total Path Cost: A* Search
We can do exactly that, combining the two evaluation functions simply by
â–ª
f(n) = g(n) + h(n)
where:
g(n): the path cost from the start node to node n;
â–ª
h(n): the estimated cost of the cheapest path from n to the goal;
â–ª
We have: f(n) = estimated cost of the cheapest solution through n.

Fundamentals of Control System

Fundamental of of Control Systems
â–ª Control System: is a control system for a process or plant, wherein control elements are distributed
throughout the system.

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_321_0]



Basic El

ements of Control System
â–ª Plant: The portion of a system which is to be controlled or regulated is called as plant or process. It is a unit
where actual processing is performed and if we observe in the figure, the input of the plant is the
controlled signal generated by a controller.
â–ª Feedback: It is a controlled action in which the output is sampled, and a proportional signal is given to the
input for automatic correction of any changes in the desired output.

[Reference: This section contains structured

data in: table_322_0]



Basic Elements of Control System
â–ª Error Detector: The function of error detector is to compare the reference input with the feedback signal. It
produces an error signal which is a difference of two inputs which are reference signal and a feedback
signal. The error signal is fed to the controller for necessary controlled action.
â–ª Controller: the element of a system within itself or external to the system which controls the plant is called
as a controller. The error signal will be

a weak signal and so it has to be amplified and then modified for
better control action.

Types of Control Systems
â–ª Open Loop System: The system whose control action is free from the output is known as the open loop
control system.
â–ª Close Loop System: The system output depends on the control action of the system.

Feedback (Closed Loop) Control System

Feedback (Closed Loop) Control System
â–ª Feedback control system handles variations
in the system.
â–ª It compensates for unexpected events.
â–ª It is a bit complex and costly compared to
Open loop system.
â–ª Stability of the system is main problem.

Linear vs Nonlinear

7. Linear vs Non-linear Control System
â€¢ A control system in which output varies linearly with the input is
called a linear control system.
8. Time Invariant vs Time Variant
â€¢ Time varying control system is a system in which one or more
parameters vary with time.
Time Invariant

Classification of Control Systems
9. Continuous Data vs Discrete Data System
â€¢ In continuous data control system, all system variables are function of a continuo

us time t.
â€¢ A discrete time control system involves one or more variables that are known only at discrete time intervals.
10. Deterministic vs Stochastic Control System
â€¢ A control system is deterministic if the response to input is predictable and repeatable.
â€¢ If not, the control system is stochastic control system.
Deterministic

Controllers for Control System
â€¢ The usefulness of PID controls lies in their general applicability to most control
systems.
â€¢ In particular, when the mathematical model of the plant is not known and
therefore analytical design methods cannot be used, PID controls prove to be
most useful.
â€¢ In the field of process control systems, it is well known that the bas

ic and
modified PID control schemes have proved their usefulness in providing
satisfactory control, although in many given situations they may not provide
optimal control.

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_363_0]



Controllers for Control System
â€¢ It is interesting to note that more than half of the industrial controllers in use
today are PID controllers or modified PID controllers.
â€¢ Because most PID controllers are adjusted on-site, many different types of
tuning rules have bee

n proposed in the literature.
â€¢ Using these tuning rules, delicate and fine tuning of PID controllers can be made
on-site.

Four Modes of Controllers
â€¢ Each mode of control has specific advantages and limitations.
â€¢ On-Off (Bang Bang) Control
â€¢ Proportional (P)
â€¢ Proportional plus Integral (PI)
â€¢ Proportional plus Derivative (PD)
â€¢ Proportional plus Integral plus Derivative (PID)

Proportional Controller (P)
â€¢ As the gain is increased the system responds faster to changes in set-point but becomes
progressively underdamped an

d eventually unstable.
â€¢ Proportional controller reduce error but cannot go to zero. It finally produces an offset error.
It can not adapt with the changing load conditions. To avoid this, another control mode is
often used in the control system which is based on the history of errors. This mode is called
integral mode.

Integral Controllers (I)
â€¢ The major advantage of integral controllers is

that they have the unique ability
to return the controlled variable back to the exact set point following a
disturbance.
â€¢ Disadvantages of the integral control mode are that it responds relatively slowly
to an error signal and that it can initially allow a large deviation at the instant
the error is produced.
â€¢ This can lead to system instability and cyclic operation. For this reason, the
integral control mode is not normally used alone, but is combined with another
control mode.

Proportional Plus Derivative Controllers (PD)
â€¢ The stability and overshoot problems that arise when a proportional controller is used at high
gain can be mitigated by

adding a term proportional to the time-derivative of the error signal.
The value of the damping can be adjusted to achieve a critically damped response.

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_376_0]



Proportional Plus Derivative Controllers (PD)
â€¢ The higher the error signal rate of change, the sooner the final control element
is positioned to the desired value.
â€¢ The added derivative action reduces initial overshoot of the measured variable,
and therefore aids in stabilizing the pr

ocess sooner.
â€¢ This control mode is called proportional plus derivative (PD) control because the
derivative section responds to the rate of change of the error signal.

â€¢ Although PD control deals neatly with the overshoot and ringing problems associated
with proportional control it does not cure the problem with the steady-state error.

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_380_0]



Tips for Designing a PID Controllers
1. Obtain an open-loop response and determine what needs to be improved.
2. Add a proportional control to improve the rise time .
3. Add a derivative control to improve the overshoot.
4. Add an integral control to eliminate the steady-state error.
5. Adjust each of K , K , and K until you obtain a desired overa

ll response.
p i d
â€¢ Lastly, please keep in mind that you do not need to implement all three controllers
(proportional, derivative, and integral) into a single system, if not necessary. For example, if
a PI controller gives a good enough response, then you don't need to implement derivative
controller to the system. Keep the controller as simple as possible.

â–ª In the NumPy section we dealt with some arrays, whose columns had each a

ndle the data this way, but in can be hard to remember,

â–ª One solution to this is to give a descriptive name to each column. These

Data Imbalance-Overfitting
â–ª If the training data is overly unbalanced, then the model will predict a non-
meaningful result.
â–ª For example, if the model is a binary classifier (e.g., apple vs. pear), and
nearly all the samples are of the same label (e.g., apple), then the model will
simply learn that everything is a label (apple).

â–ª This is called overfitting. To prevent overfitting, there needs to be a fairly
equal distribution of training samples for each classification, or range if the
label is a real value.

K-Fold Cross Validation
â–ª K-Fold is a well-known form of cross-validation.
â–ª Steps:
1. Partition the dataset into k equal-sized partitions.
2. Select one partition as the validation data.
3. Use the remaining k-1 as the training data.
4. Train the model and determine accuracy from the validation data.
5. Repeat the process k times, selecting a different partition each time for the
validation data.
6. Average t

he accuracy results.

are healthy (negative) and 10 people who have some
disease (positive). Now letâ€™s say our machine learning
model perfectly classified the 90 people as healthy but it
als

o classified the unhealthy people as healthy. What will

WHAT IS AN EXPERT SYSTEM ?
â–ª An Expert System (ES) is an example of a knowledge-based system. It was introduced around 1965 at
Stanford by Edward Feigenbaum.
â–ª â€œES is a computer program that uses artificial intelligence (AI) technologies to simulate the judgment
and behavior of a human or an organization that has expert knowledge and experience in a
particular field such as medical diagnosis, account, coding, and games, etc.â€
â–ª ES gathers data by asking the user questions about the problem. An initial set of questions can lead
to further questions depending on the user

â€™s responses.
â–ª The ES reasons what questions it needs to ask, based on the knowledge it is given. It will use the
responses from users to rule out various possibilities that will allow it eventually reach a decision or
diagnosis.

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_124_0]



WHAT IS AN EXPERT SYSTEM ?
â€¢ We rely on expert systems to help us with knowledge and understanding in a particular field.
We use them the same way as certain experts in our lives.
â€¢ For example, we will see a doctor if we have a health problem, or we will see a car mechanic
if our car will not start.
â€¢ We can similarly use an expert system; it will ask us questions about our health problem or
car problem and provide us with a diagnosis or course of action.
â€¢ ES is designed to try and replicate the judgment of a human that has expert knowledge in a
certain field. By doing this they can be used to replace or assist a human expert.

Why Develop Expert System
â–ª Human expertise:
â€¢ In short supply (few experts on task)

â€¢ Expensive to develop or hire
â€¢ Hard to get a hold of in a hurry
âœ“ Expertise difficult to apply quickly (complex tasks)
âœ“ Impractical to have humans constantly on call
â€¢ Can be lost
âœ“ Retirement/Leave job
âœ“ Death
â–ª ES serves the following functions with respect to expertise:
â€¢ Document/preserve
â€¢ Reproduce/make available
â€¢ Teach/disseminate
â–ª Computers do not get bored/tired/frustrated/scared

The General Design of an Expert System

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_130_0]



Knowledge Base
â–ª The developers of the expert system will interview a collection of experts to build the
database of knowledge.
â–ª They will look to gain two types of knowledge from the experts.
â–ª The first is factual knowledge. This is the knowledge that is widely shared.
â–ª The second type is heuristic knowledge. This is the knowledge that is more personal and is
acquired through a range of experiences and reasoning.

Knowledge Base
â–ª Once the knowledge base is built, it can be used by the expert system to inform the question
sit needs to ask and assist in providing the results.
â–ª Part of the knowledge base is the rule base. The rule base is a set of rules that will be used
to produce an output or decision by the expert

system. These rules are used by the
inference engine as a base for reasoning, to obtain a solution to a problem or a decision.
â–ª Each rule will contain two parts, the IF and the THEN. A rule can also have multiple IF parts
that will be joined together by Boolean operators including AND and OR.
â–ª Most ES will have a knowledge-based editor built into them. This allows the knowledge base
to be checked for errors and edited and updated when needed.

Inference Engine
â–ª It will ask the user questions and based on their answer it will follow a line of logic. This may
then lead to further questions and eventually a final result.
â–ª The inference engine is mostly a problem-solving tool. It organizes and controls steps to
solve the problem. To do this it often uses a chaining method. It chains together what is
known as IF-THEN rules to form a line of reasoning.
â–ª The IF part of the rule is a condition, for example, IF I am hungry. The Then part of the rule
is an action, for IF I am hungry THEN I will need to eat.

Infe

rence Engine
â–ª There are two main methods that can be used to obtain a result. The appropriate one will
depend on whether the expert system is designed to produce a final result i.e., a diagnosis
or course of action, or if it begins with a known conclusion i.e., goal.
â–ª If the process starts with a set of conditions and chaining moves towards a final conclusion,
this is called forward chaining.
â–ª If the process starts with a known conclusion, but the path to it is unknown, the chaining is
called backward chaining.

Inference Engine-Forward Chaining
â–ª In a forward chaining system, the ES will take the data input and match it to the
knowledge and rules it contains. It will keep doing this until I can reach an end goal or
outcome. Therefore, we can say a forward chaining system is data-driven.
â–ª Data is gathered about the problem and then the system infers what it can from the
data to reach a conclusion.

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_135_0]



Inference Engine-Backward Chaining
â–ª W

ith this strategy, an expert system finds out the answer to the question, â€œWhy
â–ª On the basis of what has already happened, the Inference Engine tries to find out which
conditions could have happened in the past for this result.

User Interface
â–ª The user interface is the way the
user interacts with the expert
system.
â–ª They are often graphical in nature
and have a range of selection
processes or typing methods to
allow the user to provide responses.

Shallow Expert System vs Deep Ex

pert System
â–ª Shallow Expert Systems are first-generation architecture expert systems, and which lack causal
knowledge (knowledge of the underlying causes and effects in a system) while Deep Expert
Systems are second-generation architecture expert systems that alleviate first-generation
architecture expert systemsâ€™ limitations.
â–ª Shallow Expert Systems use surface knowledge which can only represent expertise while Deep
Expert Systems use deep knowledge which can represent complex structured objects using
object models.
â–ª Shallow Expert Systems use rule-based reasoning while Deep Expert Systems combine both
rule-based reasoning and model-based reasoning.
â–ª Shallow Expert Systems use heuristics or heuristic rules or rules of thumb, which do not
guarantee optimal solutions while Deep Expert Systems use the A* algorithm which guarantees
optimality by finding solutions in reasonable computation time, in terms of, number of
transformations and steps of a search.

MYCIN: Early Medical Diagnostic System (1970s)

MYCIN: Early Medical Diagnostic System (1970s)
â–ª MYCIN was the earliest designed expert system at Stanford University in the 1970s.
â–ª Its job was to diagnose and recommend treatment for certain blood infections.
â–ª MYCIN was written in LISP Programming Language.
â–ª ~ 600 rules to diagnose the presence of certain bacteria and recommend antibiotics.
â–ª Combined rules in a more sophisticated way (Bayesian inference)
â–ª Never used in practice due to ethical concerns.
â–ª Inspired the creation of development environments for others who DID make expert
systems that were put into use.

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_143_0]



MYCIN: Early Medical Diagnostic System (

1970s)
â–ª MYCIN represented its knowledge as a set of IF-THEN rules with certainty factors. The
following is an English version of one of MYCIN's rules:
IF the infection is primary-bacteremia
AND the site of the culture is one of the sterile sites
AND the suspected portal of entry is the gastrointestinal tract
THEN there is suggestive evidence (0.7) that infection is bacteroid.
â–ª The 0.7 is roughly the certainty that the conclusion will be true given the evidence. If
the evidence is uncertain, the certainties of the bits of evidence will be combined
with the certainty of the rule to give the certainty of the conclusion.

Expert System
Advantages Disadvantages
â–ª They provide answers to questions that are outsides a â–ª They do not have the addition of common sense that
userâ€™s knowledge and experience. humans have. This means that their response can be a
logical one and cannot have a creative approach.
â–ª They can aid professionals in areas where their knowledge â–ª Errors in the knowledge base or inference engine will
and experience are a little weaker. produce errors in the results. Therefore, they are only as
good as the data and rules they are given.
â–ª As they use a logical process they are consistent in the â–ª They are not able to automatically adapt to changing

PyKE: What is statement

â€¢ Three components
1. Name of a knowledge base
2. Name of knowledge entity
â€¢ The relationship between the arguments.
3. State arguments

of these values (including nested tuples)
â€¢ Change of order arguments would change the meaning of a statement
family.son_of(son, father, mother)

PyKE: Pattern Matching
â€¢ Literal Patterns:
â€¢ Look exactly like data
family.son_of(son, father, mother)
â€¢ Only match themselves.
â€¢ Serve as inputs to Pyke.
â€¢ Used when asking â€œ Is statement X true?â€
â€¢ Pattern Variables:
â€¢ Serve as output parameters.
family.son_of($son, father, mother)
â€¢ Start with a $.
â€¢ Either bound to a value (literal pattern) or unbound.
â€¢ Used when asking â€œ Who are the sons of Thomas and Norma?â€
â€¢ Anonymous pattern variables:
family.son_of($son, $_father, mother)
â€¢ Start with $ and an underscore ($_).
â€¢ Never bound to values.
â€¢ Used when asking â€œWho are Normaâ€™s sons?â€ and donâ€™t care who are father is.

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_169_0]



PyKE: Rules
â–ª Rules have two parts:
â–ª If part (containing a list of statements called the premises)
â–ª The part (containing a list of statements called the conclusions)
â–ª Each of these if and the parts contain on

e or more facts or goals
Syntax: If [A], [B], and [C], Then [D] and [E]
Semantics: If A, B and C are true, then D and E are true.
â€¢ In order to make the rule succeed, Pyke tries to match all statements with facts within the if
clause through a process called backtracking.

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_170_0]



PyKE: Backtracking
While processing the list premises (A, B, C in the graph)
Within a ruleâ€™s if clause:
â–ª If succeeds at proving a premise:
â€¢ Proceed down to the next premise in the list.
â€¢ Trying to proceed down from the last premise in the
list (when it succeeds) causes the rule to succeed.
â–ª If fails at proving a premise:
â€¢ Back up to the prior premise in the list and try to
find another solution for it.
â€¢ Trying to back up from the first premise in the list
(when it fails) causes the rule to fail.

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_171_0]



PyKE: Forward Chaining Rules
â€¢ Use â€œ Foreachâ€, â€œAssertâ€ rather than â€œIfâ€, â€œThenâ€
â€¢ Steps:
1. Pyke star

ts with the if clause of the first rule and checks to see if it matches the known
facts
2. If so, it proceeds to the then clause of that rule (firing the rule) to asset a new fact.
3. These new facts may fire other forward-chaining rules by matching their if clause.
4. The process keeps going until no more rules could be fired.

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_172_0]



PyKE: Backward Chaining Rules
â€¢ Use â€œ Useâ€, â€œWhenâ€ rather than â€œThenâ€, â€œIfâ€
â€¢ Steps:
1. Pyke starts by finding a rule whose then part matches the goal.
2. Pyke then tries to prove all the subgoals in the if part of that rule
â€¢ Some of these subgoals are matched against facts
â€¢ Others are matched with then part of other backward-chaining rules.
3. If all of the subgoals are proved, the rule succeeds, and the original goal is proven.
Otherwise, the rule fails, and Pyke tries to find another rule, and so on.

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_173_0]

â–ª Two Search Types:

Search Strategies Performance Measure
â–ª A search strategy is defined by picking the order of node expansion.
â–ª Strategies are evaluated along the following dimensions:
â€¢ Completeness: does it always find a solution if one exists?
â€¢ Time complexity: number of nodes generated.
â€¢ Space complexity: maximum number of nodes in memory.
â€¢ Optimality: does it always find a least-cost solution?
â€¢ Systematicity: does it visit each state at most once?
â–ª Time and space complexity are measured in terms of
â€¢ b: maximum branching factor of the search tree.
â€¢ d: depth of the least-cost solution.
â€¢ m: maximum depth of the

state space (maybe âˆ)

Uninformed
Search

1. Breadth-first Search (BFS)
â–ª
All the nodes at depth d in the search tree are expanded before the nodes at depth d+1.

1. Breadth-first Search (BFS)
Advantage
â–ª If there is a solution, breadth-first search is guaranteed to find it.
â–ª If there are several solutions, breadth-first search will always find the
shallowest goal state first.
Drawbacks
â–ª All the leaf nodes of the tree must be
maintained in memory at the same time,
resulting in enormous memory consuming and
time consuming in search.

concerned about path cost.

4. Depth-limited search
â–ª Depth-limited search is an extension of DFS:
â€¢ only expands nodes with depth up to l .
â–ª For example, on the map of Romania, there are 20 cities, so we know that if
there is a solution, then it must be of length 19 at the longest.
â–ª Hard to choose an appropriate depth number l. For most problems, we will not
know a good depth limit until we have solved the problem.

5. Iterative deepening search
The iterative deepening algorithm is a
â–ª
combination of DFS and BFS algorithms. This
search algorithm finds out the best depth
limit and does it by gradually increasing the
lim

it until a goal is found.
This algorithm performs depth-first search
â–ª
up to a certain "depth limit", and it keeps
increasing the depth limit after each
iteration until the goal node is found.
1'st Iteration-----> A
The main drawback is that it repeats all the
â–ª
2'nd Iteration----> A, B, C
work of the previous phase.
3'rd Iteration------>A, B, D, E, C, F, G

6. Bidirectional search
Bidirectional search algorithm runs two simultaneous
â–ª
searches, one form initial state called as forward-search and
other from goal node called as backward-search, to find the
goal node.
Bidirectional search replaces one single search graph with
â–ª
two small subgraphs in which one starts the search from an
initial vertex and the other starts from the goal vertex.
The search stops when these two graphs intersect each other.
â–ª
Bidirectional search can use search techniques such as BFS,
â–ª
DFS, DLS, etc.
In bidirectio

nal search, one should know the goal state in
â–ª
advance.

â–ª Provide an evaluation function that returns a number purporting to describe the

â–ª Best-first Search
â–ª Use an evaluation function for each node.
â–ª Estimate of "desirabilityâ€œ.

functions
â–ª Two basic approaches
The first (named Greedy search) tries to expand the node closest to the goal;

Greedy Search: Minimize Estimated Cost to
Reach a Goal
â–ª For most problems, the cost of reaching the goal from a particular state can be
estimated but cannot be determined exactly.
â–ª A functi

on that calculates such cost estimates is called a heuristic function
(usually denoted by the letter h):
â€¢ h(n) = estimated cost of the cheapest path from the state at node n to a
goal state
â€¢
A best-first search that uses h to select the next node to expand is called greedy search.
â€¢
Strictly speaking, h can be any function at all. We will require only that h(n) = 0 if n is a goal.

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_254_0]

h (n) = straight line distance (SLD) between n and the goal location
SLD

Greedy Search in the Example (From Arad to Bucharest)
Greedy search prefers to take the biggest bite
possible out of the remaining cost to reach the
goal, without worrying about whether this will be
best in the long run.

Greedy Search V.S. Uniform-cost Search
â–ª Greedy Search
â€¢
Minimize the estimated cost to the goal h(n)
â–ª Uniform-cost Search
â€¢
Minimize the cost the p

ath so far, g(n)
â–ª Can we combine these two strategies to get the advantages of both?

Minimizing the Total Path Cost: A* Search
We can do exactly that, combining the two evaluation functions simply by
â–ª
f(n) = g(n) + h(n)
where:
g(n): the path cost from the start node to node n;
â–ª
h(n): the estimated cost of the cheapest path from n to the goal;
â–ª
We have: f(n) = estimated cost of the cheapest solution through n.

Introduction
â–ª A Block Diagram is a shorthand pictorial representation of the cause-and-
effect relationship of a system.
â–ª The interior of the rectangle representing the block usually contains a
description of or the name of the element, or the symb

ol for the
mathematical operation to be performed on the input to yield the output.
â–ª The arrows represent the direction of information or signal flow.
INPUT SYSTEM OUTPUT

Introduction
â€¢ The operations of addition and subtraction have a special representation.
â€¢ The block becomes a small circle, called a summing point, with the appropriate plus or
minus sign associated with the arrows entering the circle.
â€¢ The output is the algebraic sum of the inputs.
â€¢ Any number of inputs may enter a summing point.
â€¢ Some books put a cross in the circle.

â–ª Take Off point permits the signal to proceed unaltered along several
different paths to several destinations.

Procedures for drawing block diagram
1. Write the equations that describe the dynamic behavior for each
component.
2. Take Laplace transform of these equations, assuming zero initial
conditions.
3. Represent each Laplace-transformed equation individually in block form.
4. Assembly the elements into a complete block diagram.

Overview of the Python-Control library
Name Description
Lti(*system) Continuous-time linear time invariant system base class
StatsSpace(*system,**kwargs) Linear Time Invariant system in state-space form.
TransferFunction(*system,**kwargs) Linear Time Invariant system in transfer function form.
ZerosPolesGain(*system,**kwargs) Linear Time Invariant system in zeros, poles, gain form.
Lsim(system, U,T[,X0,interp]) Simulate output of a continuous-time linear system.
Lsim2(system, U,T[,X0,interp]) Simulate output of a continuous-time linear system, by using the ODE solver scipy.integrate.odeint.
Impulse(system[,X0,T,N]) Impulse response of continuous-time system.
Impulse2(system[,X0,T,N]) Impulse response of single-input, continuous-time linear system.
step(system[,X0,T,N]) Step response of continuous-tim

e system.
step2(system[,X0,T,N]) Step response of continuous-time system.

Overview of the Python-Control library
â–ª The python-control package is a set of python
classes and functions that implement common
operations for the analysis and design of feedback
control system.
â–ª A MATLAB compatibility module is available that
provides many of the common functions
corresponding to the commands available in the
MATLAB Control Systems Toolbox.

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_319_0]



Fundamentals of Control System

Fundamental of of Control Systems
â–ª Control System: is a control system for a process or plant, wherein control elements are distributed
throughout the system.

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_321_0]



Basic El

ements of Control System
â–ª Plant: The portion of a system which is to be controlled or regulated is called as plant or process. It is a unit
where actual processing is performed and if we observe in the figure, the input of the plant is the
controlled signal generated by a controller.
â–ª Feedback: It is a controlled action in which the output is sampled, and a proportional signal is given to the
input for automatic correction of any changes in the desired output.

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_322_0]



Basic Elements of Control System
â–ª Error Detector: The function of error detector is to compare the reference input with the feedback signal. It
produces an error signal which is a difference of two inputs which are reference signal and a feedback
signal. The error signal is fed to the controller for necessary controlled action.
â–ª Controller: the element of a system within itself or external to the system which controls the plant is called
as a controller. The error signal will be

a weak signal and so it has to be amplified and then modified for
better control action.

Types of Control Systems
â–ª Open Loop System: The system whose control action is free from the output is known as the open loop
control system.
â–ª Close Loop System: The system output depends on the control action of the system.

Open Loop Control System

â–ª Open loop control system is easy and conceptually simple
and economical.
â–ª Easier to construct.
â–ª However, it is unreliable when there are variations in the
system or unexpected environmental changes.

Feedback (Closed Loop) Control System

Feedback (Closed Loop) Control System
â–ª Feedback control system handles variations
in the system.
â–ª It compensates for unexpected events.
â–ª It is a bit complex and costly compared to
Open loop system.
â–ª Stability of the system is main problem.

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_327_0]

Classification of Control Systems

Classification of Control Systems
1. Natural Control System
â€¢ Universe
â€¢ Human Body
2. Manmade Control System
â€¢ Vehicles
â€¢ Aero planes

â€¢ Water Level Control
4. Automatic Control System
â€¢ Room temperature regulation via A.C
â€¢ Human Body Temperature control

Classification of Control Systems
5. Open-Loop Control System
â€¢ Washing Machine
â€¢ Toaster
6. Closed-Loop System
â€¢ Refrigerator
â€¢ Auto-pilot system
Linear vs Nonlinear
â€¢ Driverless cars
7. Linear vs Non-linear Control System
â€¢ A control system in which output varies linearly with the input is
called a linear control system.
8. Time Invariant vs Time Variant
â€¢ Time varying control system is a system in which one or more
parameters vary with time.
Time Invariant

Classification of Control Systems
9. Continuous Data vs Discrete Data System
â€¢ In continuous data control system, all system variables are function of a continuo

us time t.
â€¢ A discrete time control system involves one or more variables that are known only at discrete time intervals.
10. Deterministic vs Stochastic Control System
â€¢ A control system is deterministic if the response to input is predictable and repeatable.
â€¢ If not, the control system is stochastic control system.
Deterministic

â–ª The controller is an element which accepts the error in some form and decides the proper
corrective action.

Controllers for Control System
â€¢ The usefulness of PID controls lies in their general applicability to most control
systems.
â€¢ In particular, when the mathematical model of the plant is not known and
therefore analytical design methods cannot be used, PID controls prove to be
most useful.
â€¢ In the field of process control systems, it is well known that the bas

ic and
modified PID control schemes have proved their usefulness in providing
satisfactory control, although in many given situations they may not provide
optimal control.

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_363_0]



Controllers for Control System
â€¢ It is interesting to note that more than half of the industrial controllers in use
today are PID controllers or modified PID controllers.
â€¢ Because most PID controllers are adjusted on-site, many different types of
tuning rules have been proposed in the literature.
â€¢ Using these tuning rules, delicate and fine tuning of PID controllers can be made
on-site.

Four Modes of Controllers
â€¢ Each mode of control has specific advantages and limitations.
â€¢ On-Off (Bang Bang) Control
â€¢ Proportional (P)
â€¢ Proportional plus Integral (PI)
â€¢ Proportional plus Derivative (PD)
â€¢ Proportional plus Integral plus Derivative (PID)

Proportional Controller (P)
â€¢ As the gain is increased the system responds faster to changes in set-point but becomes
progressively underdamped an

d eventually unstable.
â€¢ Proportional controller reduce error but cannot go to zero. It finally produces an offset error.
It can not adapt with the changing load conditions. To avoid this, another control mode is
often used in the control system which is based on the history of errors. This mode is called
integral mode.

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_368_0]

Integral Controllers (I)
â€¢ The major advantage of integral controllers is

that they have the unique ability
to return the controlled variable back to the exact set point following a
disturbance.
â€¢ Disadvantages of the integral control mode are that it responds relatively slowly
to an error signal and that it can initially allow a large deviation at the instant
the error is produced.
â€¢ This can lead to system instability and cyclic operation. For this reason, the
integral control mode is not normally used alone, but is combined with another
control mode.

Proportional Plus Derivative Controllers (PD)
â€¢ The stability and overshoot problems that arise when a proportional controller is used at high
gain can be mitigated by adding a term proportional to the time-derivative of the error signal.
The value of the damping can be adjusted to achieve a critically damped response.

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_376_0]



Proportional Plus Derivative Controllers (PD)
â€¢ The higher the error signal rate of change, the sooner the final control element
is positioned to the desired value.
â€¢ The added derivative action reduces initial overshoot of the measured variable,
and therefore aids in stabilizing the pr

ocess sooner.
â€¢ This control mode is called proportional plus derivative (PD) control because the
derivative section responds to the rate of change of the error signal.

â€¢ Although PD control deals neatly with the overshoot and ringing problems associated

Tips for Designing a PID Controllers
1. Obtain an open-loop response and determine what needs to be improved.
2. Add a proportional control to improve the rise time .
3. Add a derivative control to improve the overshoot.
4. Add an integral control to eliminate the steady-state error.
5. Adjust each of K , K , and K until you obtain a desired overall response.
p i d
â€¢ Lastly, please keep in mind that you do not need to implement all three controllers
(proportional, derivative, and integral) into a single system, if not necessary. For example, if
a PI controller gives a good enough response, then you don't need to implement derivative
controller to the system. Keep the controller as simple as possible.

Pandas

Pandas
â–ª In the NumPy section we dealt with some arrays, whose columns had each a
special meaning. For example, the column number 0 could contain values
interpreted as years, and column 1 could contain a month, and so on.
â–ª It is possible to handle the data this way, but in can be hard to remember,
which column number corresponds to which variable. Especially, if you later
remove some column from the array, then the numbering of the remaining
columns changes.

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_427_0]



Pandas
â–ª One solution to this is to give a descriptive name to each column. These
column names stay fixed and attached to their corresponding columns, even
if we remove some of the columns.

given names as well, these are called indices in
Pandas.

arguments.

Control Flows in Python
â–ª With control flow, you can execute certain code blocks conditionally and/or
repeatedly: these basic building blocks can be combined to create
sophisticat

ed programs.
â–ª Three different categories for control flows
â€“ Loops for repetitive tasks (while, for)

given condition is satisfied.

â–ª For loop are used for sequential traversal.

â–ª The if-else statement is used to decide whether a certain statement or

Exception handling
â–ª Sometimes, you will find that you will need to handle for exceptions.
â–ª The exceptions could be invalid operations (e.g., divide by 0 or compute the
square root of a negative number) or a class of values that you simply are not
interested in.
â–ª To handle these exceptions, you can use
â€“ Break
â€“ Continue
â€“ Try-except

Break
â–ª break statement is only allowed inside a loop body.
â–ª When break executes, the loop terminates.
â–ª In practical use, a break statement is usually used with if statement to
break a loop conditionally.

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_589_0]



Break
â–ª Breaking the loop, when the wanted element is found

[Reference: This section contains structured data in: table_590_0]



Continue
â–ª Continue statement is only allowed inside a loop body.
â–ª When continue executes, the current iteration of the loop terminates, and
the execution continues with next iteration of the loo

p.
â–ª In practical use, a continue statement is usually used with if statement to
executes conditionally.

Continue
â–ª Stopping current iteration and continuing to the next one (do not break the
loop).

Try-except
â–ª Unhandled exceptions will cause your program to crash. You can handle
them using try and except statement
â–ª If the code in the try block works, the except block is skipped.
â–ª If the code in the try block fails, it jumps to the except section.
Without the try block, the
program will crash and raise
an error.
